      <title>Ambulances stuck at A&E 'unable to respond quickly to 999 calls'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/ambulances-stuck-at-ae-unable-to-respond-quickly-to-999-calls</link>
      <description><p>Seriously ill patients having to wait for hours for paramedics to arrive, says NHS boss<br></p><p><br>Patients who have a stroke or heart attack are at risk of harm because so many ambulances are stuck at A&amp;E units that they cannot respond quickly enough to 999 calls, an NHS boss has said.</p><p>The admission by a senior figure in the NHS ambulance service highlights the growing number of seriously ill patients who are having to wait for several hours – far beyond the target response time of eight minutes – for paramedics to arrive.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/ambulances-stuck-at-ae-unable-to-respond-quickly-to-999-calls">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Botched cosmetic surgery: law change urged as complaints treble</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/botched-cosmetic-surgery-law-change-urged-as-complaints-treble</link>
      <description><p>Celebrity endorsements on social media have led more to seek bargain-price fillers and Botox</p><p>An “alarming” rise in reports of botched cosmetic procedures in the UK has prompted doctors and campaigners to call for better legislation <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/jun/22/protect-children-from-online-cosmetic-surgery-apps-say-campaigners">to protect against </a>rogue practitioners.</p><p>The number of problems related to treatments such as lip fillers and Botox has almost trebled, jumping from 378 in 2016 to 931 in the space of 12 months, according to data from Save Face, a government-approved register of accredited practitioners. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/aug/21/cosmetic-surgery-clinics-named-shamed-cqc-misuse-eye-surgery">Substandard cosmetic surgery clinics to be named and shamed</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/views-from-the-nhs-frontline/2018/jan/29/i-left-nhs-to-work-as-a-cosmetic-doctor">I left the NHS to work as a cosmetic doctor. I've never looked back</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/botched-cosmetic-surgery-law-change-urged-as-complaints-treble">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cancer, Clare and me: actor Greg Wise on the death of his sister</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/feb/18/actor-greg-wise-not-that-kind-of-love-memoir-blog-sister-clare-interview</link>
      <description><p>A year after the death of his beloved sister, Wise talks about caring for Clare in her last days, and the blog, now a book, they wrote together</p><p>It is more than a year since Clare Wise, sister of the actor Greg Wise, died of cancer. She lived just down the street from the West Hampstead house her brother shares with his wife, Emma Thompson, and their daughter, Gaia. As Greg opens his front door and leads the way into his kitchen, one can see, within minutes, why he was such an indispensable carer to his sister during the last weeks of her life. Today, he has organised elevenses with good coffee and patisserie. As an actor, he is routinely cast as a reprobate (Mountbatten in <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-crown"><em>The Crown</em></a> a debatable exception). In life, he could not be nicer if he tried. And that’s precisely it: he does not appear to be trying – the charm is not fake. When I ask him how he is feeling about Clare’s death now, his eyes fill.</p><p>“I’ve had very few days when I’ve not been actively doing something about Clare, be it probate, sorting out her flat, moving furniture – or just the book.” The book is <em>Not That Kind of Love</em> and is a shared effort, written by Clare and Greg. It is fuelled by wisdom and wisecracks, a story of brotherly, and sisterly, love. Clare was 18 months Greg’s senior (he is 51) and worked for the UK Film Council and as vice president of Universal Pictures. She started a blog in 2013 (although the first lump in her breast was found in 2007) and her take on illness drew a crowd – 96,000 hits (by 2015). No wonder: her style is gallant, funny, self-deprecating. It was not until June 2015 that cancer made its terrible comeback into her bones and Greg moved into her flat to take care of her and Grably (her attention-seeking cat). He also took over the blog when she became too sick to write.</p><p>I didn’t lose Clare – she died. Passing. Losing. Slipped away… Please. We have to be able to speak death</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/feb/18/actor-greg-wise-not-that-kind-of-love-memoir-blog-sister-clare-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Will Self: ‘I’m fitter than I’ve ever been’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/will-self-im-fitter-than-ive-ever-been-walking</link>
      <description><p>The novelist, 56, on the health benefits of eating less and walking more</p><p>When I was a child and my parents separated, I went on walking holidays with my dad. My rubric’s always been to walk from home – I’m not a rambler. It’s about a sense of being and place and engagement with the environment around me.</p><p>I like wild swimming, particularly in the sea – I swim out, then float and look at the horizon. I think that’s extremely good for the imagination. I still cycle even though I was knocked off my bike a few years ago, but mostly in the summer – it’s too dangerous in the winter in London.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/will-self-im-fitter-than-ive-ever-been-walking">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Flu unites the country in an orgy of spluttering misery | Eva Wiseman</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/flu-is-uniting-the-country-in-an-orgy-of-spluttering-misery</link>
      <description><p>It’s completely horrible and potentially deadly – but at least it’s got us talking to each other</p><p>It goes spring, summer, autumn, winter, flu. This is a season of sickness, and the only season yet to be immortalised in a poem. There are no hedges and buttercups here, only the creeping mountain of toilet paper, scrunched, the smells are not those of lilacs, instead the ripe breath of someone with some terrible memory in their throat.</p><p>Flu is walking among us, poking us with its poisoned umbrellas</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/flu-is-uniting-the-country-in-an-orgy-of-spluttering-misery">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Lena Dunham’s hysterectomy choice is hers alone – whatever some people may think | Barbara Ellen</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/lena-dunham-choice-her-own-whatever-some-women-may-think</link>
      <description>The Girls creator deserves compassion, not condemnation, for her decision to have a hysterectomy<p>Only the hardest of hearts would not feel sympathy for <em>Girls</em> creator, Lena Dunham, right now. She’s <a href="https://www.vogue.com/article/lena-dunham-hysterectomy-vogue-march-2018-issue" title="">written – extremely eloquently – in <em>Vogue</em></a> about how, after many years suffering from crippling endometriosis, she elected to have a hysterectomy.</p><p>My first reaction was shock – Dunham is a young woman: did she really have to do something so final? (She writes in the article about her sadness about not being able to carry a child.) In other coverage, experts (and the not-so-expert) expressed consternation – it wasn’t even certain that the hysterectomy would eliminate all the problems. (Put very simplistically, endometriosis occurs outside the uterus and Dunham is keeping her ovaries.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/lena-dunham-choice-her-own-whatever-some-women-may-think">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Iceland law to outlaw male circumcision sparks row over religious freedom</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/iceland-ban-male-circumcision-first-european-country</link>
      <description><p>Jewish and Muslim leaders condemn first European country to propose ban</p><p>Iceland is poised to become the first European country to outlaw <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/aug/28/circumcision-the-cruellest-cut" title="">male circumcision</a> amid signs that the ritual common to both Judaism and Islam may be a new battleground over religious freedom.</p><p>A bill currently before the Icelandic parliament proposes a penalty of up to six years in prison for anyone <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/the-lay-scientist/2011/dec/06/1" title="">carrying out a circumcision other than for medical reasons</a>. Critics say the move, which has sparked alarm among religious leaders across Europe, would make life for Jews and Muslims in Iceland unsustainable.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/iceland-ban-male-circumcision-first-european-country">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Breakthrough as scientists grow sheep embryos containing human cells</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/17/breakthrough-as-scientists-grow-sheep-embryos-containing-human-cells</link>
      <description><p>Advance brings us closer to growing transplant organs inside animals or being able to genetically tailor compatible organs, say researchers</p><p>Growing human organs inside other animals has taken another step away from science-fiction, with researchers announcing they have grown sheep embryos containing human cells.</p><p>Scientists say growing human organs inside animals could not only increase supply, but also offer the possibility of genetically tailoring the organs to be compatible with the immune system of the patient receiving them, by using the patient’s own cells in the procedure, removing the possibility of rejection.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/jun/06/human-pig-embryos-qa-chimeras-transplant-organs-scientists">Human-pig embryos Q&amp;A: how would 'chimeras' make transplant organs?</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/the-h-word/2016/jun/07/human-pig-chimeras-history-xenotransplantation">Human-pig chimeras and the history of xenotransplantation</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/17/breakthrough-as-scientists-grow-sheep-embryos-containing-human-cells">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/genetics">Genetics</category>

      <title>Migrant adult social care staff 'add £4.4bn to English economy'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/17/migrant-adult-social-care-staff-add-44bn-english-economy</link>
      <description><p>Figures released to mark 1DWU event show annual contribution of migrants working in sector</p><p>Migrants working in the adult social care sector contribute £4.4bn to the English economy annually, according to figures released to mark the <a href="http://www.1daywithoutus.org/">One Day Without Us (1DWU)</a> event. </p><p>Now in its second year, 1DWU celebrates the contribution to the UK of migrants, many of whom say they feel unwelcome since an escalation in pro-Brexit rhetoric after the 2016 referendum.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/17/migrant-adult-social-care-staff-add-44bn-english-economy">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'I put my head on her knee and cried': what my 102-year-old friend taught me about grief</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/17/head-knee-cried-102-friend-taught-grief-centenarian-women</link>
      <description><p>I presumed I would be looking after the centenarian women I met. But they looked after me</p><p>Edna lives just off the M4 in a tiny brick bungalow with a wheelchair ramp. I crawled to her front door. I didn’t knock; I went straight in and put my head on her knee, pushing the Zimmer frame out of the way. And I cried, and she was still and kind and said: “I think you will always miss him. You lost your son, dear.”</p><p>On the way to Edna’s I’d had to pull the car over so the animal in me could thrash the air and grope for my dead baby – a primal scream against the loss, the regret and the pain of it all. The burden shifted marginally, briefly almost felt manageable, when I arrived at her house.</p><p>I knew the small dead person in my stomach would be hard to come back from. For months it felt impossible</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/jun/29/conversation-life-after-age-100">What is life like after 100? | The conversation</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/17/head-knee-cried-102-friend-taught-grief-centenarian-women">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Alan Maynard obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/16/alan-maynard-obituary</link>
      <description>Health economist who had a major impact on policy and practice<p>Alan Maynard, emeritus professor of health economics at the University of York, who has died aged 73, was crucial in the development of his discipline into an international profession. He also had a real impact on policy, not just in the UK.</p><p>He was, for example, an originator of the idea that better value for money and better outcomes might be achieved if family doctors were given budgets with which to buy their patients’ care. He was an early and public advocate of the principle that, before the NHS paid for them, drug companies should have to show that their new products were not just clinically effective but cost-effective. That idea resulted in the creation in 1999 of Nice, the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, a model that other countries have adopted and adapted.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/16/alan-maynard-obituary">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>A child's gender can be detected in their speech from age five, research says</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/16/child-gender-speech-age-five-research-university-minnesota</link>
      <description><p>University of Minnesota academics say boys and girls pick up speech cues from adults around them, resulting in differences</p><p>The gender of children can be picked up from their speech from as young as five years old, researchers have revealed.</p><p>While male and female children have no physiological reason for sounding different before puberty, when changes to the larynx kick in, researchers say boys and girls pick up telltale speech cues from adults around them, resulting in perceptible differences in their speech. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/jul/17/camp-the-voice-gay-rights">Do you sound gay? What our voices tell us – and what they don’t | David Shariatmadari</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jul/10/do-i-sound-gay-film-gay-voice">Do I Sound Gay? Film-maker's personal journey explores the 'gay voice'</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/16/child-gender-speech-age-five-research-university-minnesota">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>E-cigarettes and the burning issues around vaping - Science Weekly podcast</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/audio/2018/feb/16/e-cigarettes-and-the-burning-issues-around-vaping-science-weekly-podcast</link>
      <description><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/iansample">Ian Sample</a> asks: how safe is vaping? Can it help people stop smoking? And should it be available via a doctor’s prescription?</p><p><strong>Subscribe and review on <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/gb/podcast/science-weekly/id136697669?mt=2">Apple Podcasts</a>, <a href="https://soundcloud.com/guardianscienceweekly">Soundcloud</a>, <a href="https://audioboom.com/channel/guardian-science">Audioboom</a>, <a href="https://www.mixcloud.com/guardianscience/">Mixcloud</a> and <a href="https://www.acast.com/guardian-science">Acast</a>, and join the discussion on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/GuardianPodcasts/">Facebook</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/guardianaudio">Twitter</a></strong></p><p>If you’re not a smoker, it may be hard to imagine the appeal of cigarettes. The idea of inhaling thousands of chemicals into your body just doesn’t seem that tempting. It’s hard to wrap your head around the addiction if you haven’t experienced it and even more difficult to appreciate how hard it is to quit. But according to a <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/news/phe-publishes-independent-expert-e-cigarettes-evidence-review">new report</a> released by Public Health England (PHE) <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/06/vaping-is-safe-way-to-quit-smoking-says-health-body">electronic cigarettes are significantly safer than smoking</a> and can offer a potential aid for smoking cessation. But how much do we really know about vaping and its risks? Is there consensus between scientists and the public? And should the NHS be encouraging the use of e-cigarettes to aid quitters?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/audio/2018/feb/16/e-cigarettes-and-the-burning-issues-around-vaping-science-weekly-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Guilt over household chores is 'harming working women's health'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/2018/feb/16/guilt-over-household-chores-is-harming-working-womens-health-housework</link>
      <description><p>Worries over whether women are doing their ‘fair share’ has a clear impact on their health, according to a new analysis</p><p>Guilt about not doing enough housework may be harming working women’s health, according to new analysis of data from the <a href="http://www.issp.org/menu-top/home/">International Social Survey Programme</a>.<br></p><p>Over a two-year period, women in 24 countries were asked to rate the amount of household chores they do each day in terms of their perceived “fair share”. They also ranked their physical health levels.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/audio/2018/feb/16/home-truths-relationships-housework-collide-the-story-podcast">Home truths: when relationships and housework collide – The Story podcast</a> </p><p><strong>Who does what: housework around the world</strong></p><p></p><p>Am I the powerful person running a business, or am I the person incapable of keeping my house clean?</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/2018/feb/17/dirty-secret-why-housework-gender-gap">Dirty secret: why is there still a housework gender gap?</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/2018/feb/16/guilt-over-household-chores-is-harming-working-womens-health-housework">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/inequality">Inequality</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/society/equal-pay">Equal pay</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/relationships">Relationships</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/family">Family</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/gender">Gender</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/women">Women</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/society/health">Health</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/psychology">Psychology</category>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/16/brexit-deal-delay-could-put-nhs-patients-risk-tory-mp-sarah-wollaston-warns</link>
      <description><p>Sarah Wollaston tells health secretary medical businesses and services ‘remain in dark’</p><p>A delay in agreeing a Brexit transition deal could harm NHS patients, a senior MP has warned.<br></p><p>In a letter to the health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, the chair of the Commons health committee, Sarah Wollaston, said that any holdups could put patient care at risk.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/16/brexit-deal-delay-could-put-nhs-patients-risk-tory-mp-sarah-wollaston-warns">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Archaic IT is hampering the NHS. But innovation is coming</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2018/feb/16/archaic-it-nhs-innovations-guardian-technological-problems</link>
      <description><p>Panelists at a recent Guardian event outlined the technological problems facing the NHS – and pointed the way forward <br></p><p>“It’s archaic, slow, fragile and not streamlined.” So says junior doctor Nadia Masood of the chaotic and fragmented state of NHS information technology.</p><p>She described the ritual of learning a whole new set of IT systems every time her rotational training takes her to a different NHS trust. “Rotations happen every three to six months and every time there is a new system to learn. Sometimes I spend hours learning things I just don’t need to know.”</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/views-from-the-nhs-frontline/2017/nov/16/seeing-gp-smartphone-sounds-wonderful-its-not">Seeing a GP on a smartphone sounds wonderful – but it's not</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2017/oct/03/nhs-digitally-savvy-workforce-ensure-survival">The NHS needs a digitally savvy workforce to ensure its survival | Harpreet Sood</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2018/feb/16/archaic-it-nhs-innovations-guardian-technological-problems">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'She changed my world': how a teacher saved me after my mum died</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2018/feb/16/she-changed-my-world-how-a-teacher-saved-me-after-my-mum-died</link>
      <description><p>My world was rocked at the age of 12 – but my extraordinary English teacher helped me through it. Now we’re reconnecting <br></p><p>I was 12 years old, and my mum had just died from cancer. It was horrific to watch that happen to someone. My dad had an alcohol problem that mum had been managing all these years – suddenly he had a good reason to drink, and no one to stop him any more. He hit the bottle hard.</p><p>I went from being quite a high achieving student to being in the bottom quarter for English. But among all this, there was my English teacher, Miss Ward, who was so supportive. She wasn’t trained in mental health: she just saw someone who was distressed and unhappy, but who also had potential. She changed my world.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2017/aug/25/childrens-mental-health-its-time-to-put-wellbeing-on-the-curriculum">Children's mental health: it’s time to put wellbeing on the curriculum</a> </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr"><a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/FindMissWard?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#FindMissWard</a><br><br>Dear, lovely people of Twitter - Miss Ward HAS BEEN FOUND!!<br><br>Thanks to social media - a load of emails and an old school style letter we’ve exchanged some emails and we’ll be meeting up soon<br><br>She wishes to remain anonymous &amp; I’ll respect that<br><br>Thank you Twitter!!</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2018/feb/16/she-changed-my-world-how-a-teacher-saved-me-after-my-mum-died">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>DIY faecal transplants carry risks including HIV and hepatitis, warn experts</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/15/diy-faecal-transplants-carry-risks-including-hiv-and-hepatitis-warn-experts</link>
      <description><p>Faecal transplants have been used in medical settings to tackle superbugs, but following YouTube videos at home is too risky, say researchers</p><p>Concerns have been raised about the growing trend for DIY faecal transplants, with experts fearing such attempts could put individuals at an increased risk of HIV and hepatitis as well as conditions ranging from Parkinson’s and multiple sclerosis to obesity and sleep disorders.</p><p>The <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/mar/31/bacteria-faecal-transplant-gut-mary-roach-gulp">transfer of faeces from one human to another</a> has gained attention as a growing number of studies have suggested links between microbes in the gut and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/aug/01/is-your-gut-making-you-sick">a host of health problems</a>, from autoimmune diseases to anxiety.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/jan/29/magical-microbes-how-to-feed-your-gut">How to feed your gut</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/aug/25/gut-reaction-surprising-power-of-microbes">Gut reaction: the surprising power of microbes | Ed Yong</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/15/diy-faecal-transplants-carry-risks-including-hiv-and-hepatitis-warn-experts">Continue reading...</a></description>
